metadata.title: Cancer Prevention and Exercise
anatomical location body part affected: Skeletal muscle and adipose tissue; widespread systemic suppression of cancer cells
description: Prescription of leisure-time  physical activity or aerobic exercise is a well-established,evidence-based  lifestyle component for promoting health and increasing longevity. –For example, authors of a 2015 meta-analysis  of 6 prospective cohorts (661,137 men and women; median age, 62 years) in the United States and Europe found that participantswith7.5 metabolic-equivalent (MET)  hours of physical activity per week (i.e., 75 vigorous-intensity  or 150 moderate-intensity  minutes) or more had 31% to 37% lower all-cause  mortality from 1992 to 2003 (116,686 deaths were included) compared to those with no leisure time activity(1) –New evidence also supports prescription of leisure time physical activity or aerobic exercise for prevention of cancer. A 2016 meta-analysis  of 12 prospective cohorts (1.44 million men and women, median age, 59 years) in the United States and Europe found that among 186,932 participants with incident cancers from 1987 to 2004, those at the upper levels of MET hours per week had statistically significant lower risks of 13 types of cancer than those at the lower levels of MET hours. The included cancers were colon, breast, endometrium, esophageal adenocarcinoma, liver, gastric cardia, kidney, myeloid leukemia, myeloma, head, neck, rectum, and bladder. Moreover, high physical activity reduced the risk for most of these cancers even in overweight/obese participants and smokers(2)

Health care professionals should counsel physically inactive patients about the cancer risk associated with insufficient exercise and prescribe an individualized aerobic training program according to guidelines(3)
This Clinical Review addresses the potential anticancer role of exercise training in healthy persons and those with high cancer risk

presentation signs and symptoms: Insufficient regular muscular activity/exercise for health promotion, or to maintain physical fitness, or to prevent cancer(2)
Other risk factors for cancer such as smoking
Reduced physical fitness for age and sex(3) –Reduced aerobic work capacity (AWC) –Reduced strength
Excess body fat –Overweight: body mass index (BMI) of 25-29.9  kg/m2 –Obese: BMI of 30 kg/m2 or more  Causes, Pathophysiology & Risk Factors

causes:: Series of mutations (often idiopathic) in normal cells that lead to defective cellular functions and uninhibited growth–Genetic (inherited)predisposition (family history)–Environmental carcinogens (cancer-causing  substances, such as cigarette smoke)–Infectious viruses
pathophysiology:: Cancer is a neoplastic disease that originates in normal tissue–There are more than 100 types of cancer. Each is named for the type of cancer cell in which the abnormal growth began–Six hallmark pathogenetic characteristics of cancer cells(4)-Evade growth inhibitors-Sustain proliferative signaling, leading to tumorigenesis-Cross cell boundaries,invade nearby tissues, and spread (metastasize) to other regions of the body-Induce angiogenesis-Enable replicative immortality-Resist cell death (apoptosis)

At least 7.5 metabolic-equivalent (MET)  hours of leisure-time physical activity,such as walking, jogging, bicycling, andswimming,have been shown to reduce the risk of developing many types of cancer. The mechanisms of this anticancerbenefit are likely related to the biochemical products that muscles release during exercise(2)–Skeletal muscle synthesizes cytokines, growth factors, and additional peptides that have paracrine, autocrine, or endocrineeffects on other tissues. These muscle-derived products are called myokines. The most studied myokine is the gp130receptor cytokine interleukin-6  (IL-6),  which increases up to 100-fold  in the blood during exercise(5)–Some anticancer myokines have immunoregulatory and antiproliferative effects on tumors by inducing apoptosis indeveloping cancer cells(6,7,8)
risk factors:: Environmental carcinogens such as tobacco smoke
Insufficient leisure-time  muscular activity/regular exercise (less than 7.5 MET hours per week) to improve or maintainphysical fitness(2)

Excess body fatness and smoking apparently do not increase the risk of many cancers in persons with high leisure-timephysical activity, other than smoking-related  lung cancer(2)Overall Contraindications/Precautions to Exercise
absolute contraindications: Recent history of myocardial infarction (MI), unstable angina, symptomatic cardiac arrhythmias, or severe aortic stenosis
Ongoing heart infection or thromboembolic disease such as deep venous thrombosis (DVT)
Patient has not recovered from acute illness
Inability to safely walk on a treadmill or pedal an ergometer due to orthopedic condition
relative contraindications: Prior history of coronary heart disease or cardiac arrhythmias
Metabolic disease that impairs low-level  exercise

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Determine the onset of any condition that requires special consideration for exercise prescription(3)

course of treatment.medical management: Determine what treatments the patient has received for a chronic disease condition that reduces physical functioning
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Is the patient taking medications that affect the heart rate (HR) and/or blood pressure (BP) responses to exercise. For example, betablockers  lower exercise HR and BP and angiotensin-converting  enzyme (ACE) inhibitors reduce BP
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Usual laboratory tests prior to exercise testing aim to establish the patient’s health status and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk profile. Patients referred for exercise counseling may not have had preliminary diagnostic testing
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g. ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g. acupuncture) and whether they help or not
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, worst and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing which could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient have pulmonary problems and the need for supplemental oxygen? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes ___/No ___ -If Yes, describe

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about their medical problems,(e.g., diabetes, cancer, heart disease, lung disease, chronic fatigue syndrome, fibromyalgia, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.). Document coexisting conditions or other symptoms that may complicate exercise, such as muscle atrophy, poor balance, or history of falls. Document any symptoms that may indicate need for referral to physician, such as cognitive or neurological deficits. Are there coexisting movement problems such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, muscular dystrophy, or Parkinson’s disease? Is there a history of obesity, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, hypertension, or pulmonary disease?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: (e.g., does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?. Are there any environmental exposures to carcinogens in the workplace?)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient have any prior functional limitation(s)? Is any adaptive equipment used at home? Assess if applicable
social and occupational history.living environment: (e.g., stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc.) Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: –Relevant tests and measures:  While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for and proper use of ambulatory assistive devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess both static and dynamic standing balance, as well as unilateral balance. If full weight-bearing (FWB), assess balance in standing on each leg, walking on toes, and timed single-leg  stand. Observe for deficits in hip strategies in an effort to maintain balance. Use Berg Balance Scale (BBS), as indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulsesTesting may be indicated to establish patient’s ability for treadmill exercise. Assess ability in sit-to-stand,  turning, stooping, kneeling, squatting, and sitting down. Functional mobility can also be assessed by marching-on-the-spot,  ability to use stairs, and Timed Up and Go (TUG) test
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess walking agility, including tandem gait and turns. Note ability to change directions while walking. Assess gait safety with the Dynamic Gate Index (DGI), as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Scan functional strength of the lower and upper extremities with manual muscle testing (MMT)Assess for any reported pain with V AS
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess general posture and lower extremity alignment, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Scan functional range of motion (ROM) and flexibility of the upper and lower extremities
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Graded exercise testing should be conducted according to established guidelines.(3) To ensure safety and effectiveness, a physician, clinical exercise physiologist, or physical therapist with special training should administer the exercise test andT910667

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Insufficient leisure-time  physical activity or regular exercise for prevention of cancer/ reduced functional endurance and strength for general activities
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Occupational therapist for difficulties with ADLs, personal trainer for supervised fitness program in a home/gym/pool setting, dietitian for assessment of contributing nutritional factors for overweight patients
treatment summary: The prescribed exercise program should aim for a target threshold amount of exercise for prevention of cancer of 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity  to 150 minutes of moderate-intensity  physical activity per week, preferably in 3 to 5 days per week

Guidelines are available for exercise testing and for aerobic or resistance exercise training after a cardiac event. Exercise prescription should always be individualized for type, frequency, duration, intensity, and progression of exercise sessions, as appropriate for the patient(3)

Recommendations for aerobic exercise prescription(3) –Walking (outdoors or treadmill), cycling (outdoors or ergometer), rowing, stair climbing, arm/leg ergometry, and other endurance types of exercise as available (e.g., swimming, aquatic aerobics) –At least 3 days a week for 12 or more weeks –Twenty to 40 minutes of continuous or interval training per session –It is suggested that exercise be progressed cautiously along with use of Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) or Talk Test. Talk Test is ability to talk while exercising without becoming breathless and usually keeps patient at a moderate level of exertion, or below their anaerobic threshold

Recommendations for resistance exercise prescription(3) –Calisthenics, elastic bands, cuff or hand weights, dumbbells, free weights, wall pulleys, weight machines, and other types of resistance exercise –Two to 3 days per week –One to 3 sets of 10-15  repetitions of 8-10 exercises; 40-50% maximum voluntary contraction (MVC) while being sure to avoid Valsalva maneuver
Recommendations for flexibility exercises –Static stretching of the upper and lower body –Two to 3 days a week; hold for 10-30  seconds
Include a good warm-up  and cool-down  in each exercise session
Provide progressive updates to the exercise prescription and modify as indicated
If no ETT data are available, do not base exercise prescription on HR
